message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The middle part of the greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the short gastric arteries, which arise from the splenic artery. Ligating a portion of the splenic artery is necessary to complete the resection of that portion of the stomach during a sleeve gastrectomy. None of the other options supply this area of the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the branches of the splenic artery. Ligating a portion of the arterial supply to this part of the stomach would require ligating a branch of the splenic artery. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach receives its arterial blood supply from the left and right gastric arteries and the short gastric arteries, which are branches of the splenic artery. Therefore, the vessel that will need to be ligated in order to complete the resection is the splenic artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery, both of which branch off the splenic artery. Therefore, the vessel that will need to be ligated in order to complete the resection is the splenic artery. None of the other options supply the greater curvature of the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In a sleeve gastrectomy, a large portion of the stomach along the middle part of the greater curvature is removed. The arterial supply to this part of the stomach is provided by the short gastric arteries, which arise from the splenic artery. Therefore, the vessel that will need to be ligated in order to complete the resection is the splenic artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vessels that supply the greater curvature of the stomach are branches of the splenic artery, specifically the short gastric arteries. Therefore, it is likely that the surgeon will need to ligate a portion of the splenic artery to complete the resection during the sleeve gastrectomy. The other arteries listed do not supply the portion of the stomach that will be removed during the surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach is mainly supplied by the left gastroepiploic artery, which arises from the splenic artery. Therefore, the vessel that will need to be ligated in order to complete the resection is the splenic artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach is primarily served by the left gastroepiploic artery, which is a branch of the splenic artery. Therefore, ligating a portion of the arterial supply to this part of the stomach would require ligating the splenic artery. Option A is incorrect because the right gastric artery supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach. Option C is incorrect because the right gastroepiploic artery primarily supplies the right side of the greater curvature of the stomach. Option D is incorrect because the gastroduodenal artery primarily supplies the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The middle part of the greater curvature is supplied by the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery, which both arise from the splenic artery. Therefore, ligating a portion of the arterial supply to this part of the stomach will require ligating the splenic artery. The other vessels listed do not supply this region of the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gastric artery branches into the left and right gastric arteries, which join to form the gastroduodenal artery. The gastroduodenal artery then gives rise to the right gastroepiploic artery and the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery. Therefore, the vessel that will need to be ligated is the splenic artery, which gives rise to the left gastroepiploic artery, a primary blood supply to the stomach along the greater curvature.
